p: In another strategy, siRNA also appear as a promising tool for the control of SARS-CoV-2. In 2005, Wu et al. evaluated the effectiveness of siRNA targeted to the coding sequences of the S protein of SARS-CoV-1, which is responsible for the pathogenicity of the virus, and the 3â€²-UTR region and obtained inhibitory effects on the replication of the virus in the Vero E6 cell line [ 158]. Using the same strategy, Li et al. showed interesting results for the control of SARS-CoV-1 using siRNA [ 159]. Gene expression and viral replication were inhibited in Vero E6 cells employing siRNAs, which were prepared targeting a conserved leader sequence common to all coronaviruses. Considering the existing similarities between SARS-CoV-1 and SARS-CoV-2 [ 160, 161], these alternatives may be considered in the search for solutions against COVID-19. In a letter to the editor of EXCLI Journal, Ghosh et al. proposed the use of siRNA for the treatment of COVID-19 [ 162].
